D.S.; D.Y. by and through his next friend   
10  JULIE KELLOGG-MORTENSEN; H.A.   
by and through his next friend KRISTEN   
11 
BISHOPP; and DISABILITY RIGHTS  No. 2:21-cv-00113-BJR 
WASHINGTON, a nonprofit membership   
12 
organization for the federally mandated   
Protection and Advocacy Systems,  ORDER GRANTING 
13 
  PLAINTIFFS’ UNOPPOSED 
14    Plaintiffs,  MOTION FOR ORDER 
  APPROVING ATTORNEYS’ 
15 
  v.  FEES AND COSTS FOLLOWING 
  MEDIATION 
16 
WASHINGTON STATE 
17  DEPARTMENT OF CHILDREN, 
YOUTH, AND FAMILIES; and ROSS 
18  HUNTER, in his official capacity as 
Secretary of the Washington State 
19 
Department of Children, Youth, and 
Families, 
20 
 
21    Defendants. 
 
22 
THIS MATTER having come before the Court on Plaintiffs’ Unopposed Motion for Order 
23 
Approving Attorneys’ Fees and Costs Following Mediation, and having been duly considered, the 
24 
25  Court makes the following findings:  
26 
  ORDER - 1 
 

Case 2:21-cv-00113-BJR   Document 124   Filed 09/21/22   Page 2 of 6
 
 
1.  Plaintiffs filed this class action lawsuit on January 28, 2021, alleging that they and 
1 
2  a class of foster children with disabilities were being harmed by Defendants’ failure to correct 
3 
systemic deficiencies in Washington State’s child welfare system.  Plaintiffs sought declaratory 
4 
and injunctive relief, alleging that Defendants’ failures violate the rights of foster children with 
5 
disabilities under the United States Constitution; Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act 
6 
(“ADA”), 42 U.S.C. § 12131 et seq.; Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (“Rehabilitation 
7 
Act”), 29 U.S.C. § 794; and the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 (“AACWA”), 
8 
9  42 U.S.C. §§ 621 et seq., 670 et seq.  Dkt. 1.   
10  2.  On June 29, 2021, the Court granted in part Plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary 
11 
injunction, which required Defendants to address practices for children in “placement exceptions,” 
12 
including the use of hotel and government offices.  Dkt. 63.  Plaintiffs’ counsel subsequently 
13 
negotiated with Defendants to stipulate to the definition of a class, which was certified on 
14 
September 22, 2021.  Dkt. 77. 
15 
3.  On June 15, 2021, the parties began engaging in mediation.  Over the course of the 
16 
17  next year, they met over a dozen times and continuously exchanged numerous written proposals 
18  and settlement drafts, while also engaging in discovery.  These efforts resulted in the Settlement 
19 
Agreement, which was executed on June 6, 2022, and was granted preliminary approval by the 
20 
Court on June 24, 2022.  Dkt. 97.  The Settlement Agreement provides for a comprehensive array 
21 
of remedies to expand placement options and improve practices to better serve the complex and 
22 
intersectional needs of the Class and their families.   
23 
4.  The Settlement Agreement itself affirms “an agreement that attorneys’ fees, costs, 
24 
25  and expenses shall be paid to Plaintiffs’ Counsel for the litigation, mediation, and post-settlement 
26 
monitoring through the date Defendants’ obligations under this Agreement terminate.”  Dkt. 94-1 
  ORDER - 2 
 

Case 2:21-cv-00113-BJR   Document 124   Filed 09/21/22   Page 3 of 6
 
 
¶ 56.  After the parties negotiated and submitted their Settlement Agreement for preliminary 
1 
2  approval, they mediated on June 21, 2022, and reached an agreement for Defendants to pay 
3 
Plaintiffs $2,150,000.00 for their reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs from case inception to the 
4 
date this Court enters final approval on the Settlement Agreement.  Plaintiffs represent that their 
5 
actual attorneys’ fees and costs, after the exercise of billing judgment to remove any excess, 
6 
redundant, or unreasonably duplicative time, and applying a lodestar, is at least approximately 
7 
$2,601,434.30, and their expenses are $19,258.27 as of July 20, 2022. 
8 
9  5.  Plaintiffs have filed an unopposed motion seeking approval of the mediated total 
10  amount of $2,150,000.00 attorneys’ fees and costs.  They submit with their motion detailed time 
11 
logs and declarations of Plaintiffs’ counsel, documentation to support their billing rates, and 
12 
records of necessary litigation expenditures.  The Court has reviewed these documents and the 
13 
summary of the time spent in this litigation.  These fees and costs are for necessary time spent 
14 
engaging in extensive pre-lawsuit negotiation and investigation; filing the complaint and obtaining 
15 
a preliminary injunction and class certification; conducting wide-ranging discovery; and mediating 
16 
17  extensively  with  the  State  of  Washington  toward  the  Settlement  Agreement  that  requires 
18  implementation of child welfare reforms across the state.  The litigation costs and expenditures 
19 
incurred by Plaintiffs’ counsel were necessary and are also fully documented.  
20 
6.  The Court has reviewed the hourly rates of the attorneys and paralegals that 
21 
recorded time in this litigation, which the Court finds to be in line with the hourly rates charged in 
22 
the Seattle market for reasonably comparable work performed by attorneys of reasonably similar 
23 
skill, experience, and reputation.  
24 
25  7.  Plaintiffs are the prevailing party and are entitled to their reasonable attorneys’ fees 
26 
and costs under 42 U.S.C. § 1988.  Plaintiffs represent the amount of time expended, hourly rates 
  ORDER - 3 
 

Case 2:21-cv-00113-BJR   Document 124   Filed 09/21/22   Page 4 of 6
 
 
requested,  and  reasonable  costs  for  the  covered  period  results  in  a  potential  lodestar  of 
1 
2  $2,620,692,57.  The $2,150,000.000 agreed fee award thus represents approximately an 18% 
3 
reduction in the lodestar and costs that might otherwise be recoverable by Plaintiffs’ counsel.  
4 
Given the scope and complexity of this litigation, the amount of time expended and documented 
5 
in the course of representing Plaintiffs in this matter, the discovery undertaken by Plaintiffs, the 
6 
hourly rates Plaintiffs’ counsel have requested, the costs Plaintiffs’ counsel have incurred and 
7 
documented, and the favorable results achieved, the Court finds that the stipulated $2,150,000.00 
8 
9  attorneys’ fees and costs award is fair and reasonable in this matter.  
10  8.  As indicated on the Notice of Proposed  Class Action Settlement, which was 
11 
distributed to the Class in accordance with the approved Notice Plan (see Dkts. 97-100), Plaintiffs 
12 
have posted their Unopposed Motion for Approval of Attorneys’ Fees and Costs on the Disability 
13 
Rights Washington website at https://www.disabilityrightswa.org/cases/d-s-v-washington-state-
14 
department-of-children-youth-and-families and the National Center for Youth Law website at 
15 
https://youthlaw.org/settlement-ds-v-washington-state-dcyf.  Notice has been directed to class 
16 
17  members in a reasonable manner pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(h). 
18  9.  On  August  12,  2022,  James  and  Shaylee  Medicraft  filed  objections  to  the 
19 
Settlement Agreement on behalf of their children.  Dkt. 111.1  Their objections point to certain 
20 
signs of collusion between class counsel and defendants in reaching a settlement agreement, laid 
21 
out in In re Bluetooth Headset Product Liability Litigation, 654 F.3d 935 (9th Cir. 2011), that the 
22 
Medicrafts suggest are present in this case.  Specifically, according to the Medicrafts, (1) “the class 
23 
24 
 
25  1 As counsel for the Medicrafts conceded during the final approval hearing held before the Court on September 15, 
2022, the Medicrafts are not class members and thus have no standing to object to the proposed settlement.  See Fed. 
26  R. Civ. P. 23(e)(5)(A) (“[a]ny class member may object to the propos[ed] [settlement] if it requires court approval” 
(emphasis added)).  
  ORDER - 4 
 

Case 2:21-cv-00113-BJR   Document 124   Filed 09/21/22   Page 5 of 6
 
 
receive[d] no monetary distribution but class counsel are amply rewarded”; (2) “the parties 
1 
2  negotiate[d] a ‘clear sailing’ arrangement providing for the payment of attorneys’ fees separate 
3 
and apart from class funds”; and (3) “the parties arrange[d] for fees not awarded to revert to 
4 
defendants rather than be added to the class fund.”  Id. at 947.  The Court finds that none of these 
5 
Bluetooth factors are present or otherwise suggest collusion here.  As to the first Bluetooth factor, 
6 
Plaintiffs’ lawsuit never sought damages, but instead pursued only injunctive relief of the sort 
7 
contemplated by the Settlement Agreement.  As to the second factor, the Settlement Agreement 
8 
9  contained no agreed amount for attorneys’ fees that Defendants promised not to challenge.  Rather, 
10  as noted above, negotiations as to attorneys’ fees did not begin until the Settlement Agreement 
11 
was already signed, and the Agreement contemplated a contested motion if the parties could not 
12 
reach consensus on the amount of fees.  Finally, the third Bluetooth factor concerning a “reverter” 
13 
clause does not apply to a settlement, as here, for injunctive relief.  See Campbell v. Facebook, 
14 
Inc.,  951  F.3d  1106,  1127  (9th  Cir.  2020)  (“An  injunctive-relief-only  class  settlement,  by 
15 
definition, has no fund into which any fees not awarded by the court could possibly revert.”).  For 
16 
17  the above reasons, the Court finds that the Medicrafts’ objections to Plaintiffs’ attorneys’ fees lack 
18  merit.     
19 
10.  Absent any meritorious objection to the stipulated $2,150,000.00 attorneys’ fees 
20 
and costs award, and finding it to be fair and reasonable in this matter, the Court approves the 
21 
award.   
22 
Now, therefore, the Court hereby ORDERS that, pursuant to Rule 23(h) of the Federal 
23 
Rules  of  Civil  Procedure  and  42  U.S.C.  §  1988,  Plaintiffs’  Unopposed  Motion  for  Order 
24 
25  Approving Attorneys’ Fees and Costs Following Mediation is GRANTED and the parties’ agreed 
26 
upon attorneys’ fees and costs award of $2,150,000.00 to Plaintiffs is approved.  In accordance 
  ORDER - 5 
 

Case 2:21-cv-00113-BJR   Document 124   Filed 09/21/22   Page 6 of 6
 
 
with their agreement, Defendants shall pay $2,150,000.00 to Plaintiffs’ counsel within thirty (30) 
1 
2  days following the entry of this Order. 
3 
IT IS SO ORDERED.  
4 
Dated:  September 21, 2022 
5 
6 
            _______________________________ 
7            Barbara Jacobs Rothstein 
          U.S. District Court Judge

  ORDER - 6

documents.title: Order Granting Joint Motion for Final Approval of Class Action Settlement Agreement
documents.text:
Case 2:21-cv-00113-BJR   Document 123   Filed 09/21/22   Page 1 of 4
 
 
The Honorable Barbara J. Rothstein 
1 
 
2   
 
3 
 
 
4 
 
5   
 
6   
 
7  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON  
8 
AT SEATTLE 
 
9 
D.S.; D.Y. by and through his next friend   
10  JULIE KELLOGG-MORTENSEN; H.A.   
by and through his next friend KRISTEN   
11 
BISHOPP; and DISABILITY RIGHTS  No. 2:21-cv-00113-BJR 
WASHINGTON, a nonprofit membership   
12 
organization for the federally mandated   
Protection and Advocacy Systems,  ORDER GRANTING JOINT 
13 
  MOTION FOR FINAL 
14    Plaintiffs,  APPROVAL OF CLASS ACTION 
  SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT 
15 
  v. 
 
16 
WASHINGTON STATE 
17  DEPARTMENT OF CHILDREN, 
YOUTH, AND FAMILIES; and ROSS 
18  HUNTER, in his official capacity as 
Secretary of the Washington State 
19 
Department of Children, Youth, and 
Families, 
20 
 
21    Defendants. 
 
22 
THIS MATTER having come before the Court on the parties’ Joint Motion for Final 
23 
Approval of Class Settlement Agreement and having been duly considered, the Court makes the 
24 
25  following findings: 
26 
  ORDER - 1 
 

Case 2:21-cv-00113-BJR   Document 123   Filed 09/21/22   Page 2 of 4
 
 
The Court has jurisdiction over the claims against all Defendants pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§ 
1 
2  1331, 1343(a).  Venue is proper in the Western District of Washington pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 
3 
1391(b).  
4 
The Court, in its June 24, 2022 Order, preliminarily approved the parties’ proposed 
5 
Settlement Agreement.  Dkt. 97.  The Court’s Order further approved the parties’ notice to class 
6 
members regarding the proposed settlement (see Declaration of Susan Kas (“Kas Decl.,” Dkt. 93-
7 
2), Ex. B), and the method for distributing the notice as described in the Notice Plan (see Kas 
8 
9  Decl., Ex. C).  The Order also provided class members until August 12, 2022 to submit written 
10  objections.   
11 
The Court conducted a final approval hearing, via Zoom, on September 15, 2022.  Counsel 
12 
for Plaintiffs and Defendants presented argument as to why the Settlement Agreement is fair, 
13 
reasonable, and adequate and should be approved.  The Court also heard arguments from counsel 
14 
for James and Shaylee Medicraft, who filed objections to the Settlement Agreement on behalf of 
15 
their children.  See Dkt. 111.  The Medicrafts, while not objecting to the substance of the 
16 
17  Settlement Agreement, argued that they did not receive individual notice; that the proposed 
18  settlement did not provide class members with an opt-out procedure; and that this case should 
19 
proceed to trial in order to benefit class members with factual findings that would collaterally estop 
20 
Defendants in subsequent individual litigations for damages.  See id.  Finally, the Court heard from 
21 
several social work practitioners, and parents of children who had been in Defendants’ custody, 
22 
who expressed both satisfaction and concerns with the proposed Settlement Agreement.  The Court 
23 
finds that class members and others affected by the proposed Settlement Agreement received 
24 
25  adequate opportunity to object.  
26 
  ORDER - 2 
 

Case 2:21-cv-00113-BJR   Document 123   Filed 09/21/22   Page 3 of 4
 
 
As stated on the record during the final approval hearing, the Court finds, as counsel for 
1 
2  the Medicrafts conceded, that the Medicrafts are not class members and therefore have no standing 
3 
to object to the proposed settlement.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(e)(5)(A) (“[a]ny class member may 
4 
object to the propos[ed] [settlement] if it requires court approval” (emphasis added)).  The Court 
5 
also finds that the parties complied with the Notice Plan in all material respects, meeting the due 
6 
process requirements of the United States Constitution and Rule 23(e) of the Federal Rules of Civil 
7 
Procedure.  See Dkts. 98-100.  Given that the class in this case was certified under Rule 23(b)(2) 
8 
9  (see Dkt. 77), individual notice to class members was not required.  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(c)(2)(A); 
10  Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes, 564 U.S. 338, 363 (2011) (recognizing that Rule 23(b)(2) “does 
11 
not require that class members be given notice”).  For the same reason, the proposed settlement 
12 
was not required to provide class members with an opt-out procedure.  See Wal-Mart Stores, 564 
13 
U.S. at 362 (recognizing that Rule 23 “provides no opportunity for … (b)(2) class members to opt 
14 
out”).   
15 
The Court finds that the proposed Settlement Agreement (Dkt. 94-1) is fair, reasonable, 
16 
17  adequate, and beneficial to class members in light of the relief Plaintiffs have obtained in 
18  settlement to achieve the goals of the litigation.  Further litigation would expose both sides to risk 
19 
and expense, given the complexity of this lawsuit and the likely duration of litigation.  The 
20 
Settlement Agreement is the result of arms’ length negotiations, conducted with the assistance of 
21 
a skilled neutral mediator and after thorough factual and legal investigation and discovery, and is 
22 
not the product of fraud, collusion, or overreaching.  While the proposed settlement will not result 
23 
in factual findings that could later be used in prosecuting individual lawsuits seeking damages, 
24 
25  Plaintiffs, in this case, never sought damages, but instead pursued only injunctive relief of the sort 
26 
contemplated by the Settlement Agreement.  No class member or interested party has raised 
  ORDER - 3 
 

Case 2:21-cv-00113-BJR   Document 123   Filed 09/21/22   Page 4 of 4
 
 
concerns that alter the  underlying fairness,  reasonableness,  and adequacy of the Settlement 
1 
2  Agreement. 
3 
The Court, having fully considered the matter and good cause appearing, hereby ORDERS: 
4 
1.  The parties’ Joint Motion for Final Approval of Class Action Settlement Agreement is 
5 
GRANTED.  The Court finds and concludes that the settlement is fair, reasonable, and 
6 
adequate. 
7 
2.  The parties’ Settlement Agreement and Order, attached as Exhibit A to the Declaration 
8 
9  of Susan Kas in Support of Plaintiffs’ Motion for Preliminary Approval (Dkt. 94-1) is 
10  APPROVED and incorporated herein. 
11 
3.  The parties to the Settlement Agreement and Order shall perform all of their obligations 
12 
thereunder.  The case is DISMISSED, but the Court shall retain jurisdiction over the 
13 
matter  to  enforce  the  provisions  of  the  Settlement  Agreement  and  Order  until 
14 
Defendants’ obligations terminate under paragraph 36 of the Agreement.  
15 
4.  The Settlement Agreement and Order is binding on class members.  It settles all of 
16 
17  Plaintiffs’ claims for class-wide injunctive relief against Defendants that were asserted 
18  in the Complaint filed on January 28, 2021. 
19 
IT IS SO ORDERED.  
20 
Dated:  September 21, 2022 
21 
 
22 
          _______________________________ 
23 
          Barbara Jacobs Rothstein 
          U.S. District Court Judge 
24 
 
25 
 
26 
  ORDER - 4
